stimulusHtml: A wave on a string approaches a piece of cardboard and passes through a narrow slit in the cardboard. The wave has amplitude A as it approaches the slit, which is much longer than A . The wave on the other side of the slit has amplitude A3 . Which of the following could explain why the amplitude A3 on the other side of the slit is smaller?
choicesHtml: The wave is polarized vertically and the slit is aligned horizontally, so the amplitude would be reduced.
The wave is polarized vertically and the slit is aligned vertically, but the finite width of the slit means only some of the wave will pass through the slit.
The wave is polarized horizontally and the slit is aligned vertically, so only vertical components of the wave pass through the slit.
The wave is polarized at some angle between horizontal and vertical, and the slit is aligned vertically, so only the vertical component of the wave will pass through the slit.
